title: Uber Stock Tumbled After London Granted It a License for Just Two Month
text:
Text size

Uber Technologies (ticker: UBER) shares plunged over 5% on Tuesday as the ride-sharing company lost its latest effort to secure a long-term operating license in London—one of the company’s most important markets. London’s main transportation regulator, Transport for London, granted Uber a two-month license on Tuesday instead. That’s among the shortest terms the agency has ever granted.

The back story. Uber was running on a 15-month probationary license in London, which was set to expire before midnight on Wednesday. The Silicon Valley giant was rejected by the TfL in 2017 for a renewal of its private-hire license on concerns of potential public safety and governance issues related to data breaches, crime reporting, and drivers’ background checks.

In June 2018, British judge Emma Arbuthnot granted Uber a short-term license for 15 months—instead of the usual five-year term—after the ride-sharing company made some changes to its operation and promised to commit to the 14 conditions laid out by the TfL, including board composition, compliance protocol, and criminal reporting policy.

What's new. Ahead of the expiration of Uber’s 15-month license, TfL said on Tuesday it still needed to conduct more review on the company before considering any potential longer-term license and only gave the company a two-month permit instead.

The new two-month license will have the same conditions that Uber has been subject to over the last 15 months, according to a TfL statement, along with new conditions to ensure passenger safety. The new conditions cover ride sharing, appropriate insurance and driver document checks by Uber.

“TfL’s original decision not to license [Uber London Limited] has led to the app-based firm improving its culture and governance,” wrote the regulator in the statement, “TfL is requesting additional material from [Uber London Limited] and this additional information will help inform any future licensing decision.”

Jamie Heywood, Uber’s regional general manager for Northern & Eastern Europe, said the company will continue to work closely with the regulator and provide any additional information needed.

“Over the past two years, we’ve launched a range of new safety features in the app, introduced better protections for drivers and our Clean Air Plan is helping to tackle air pollution,” said Heywood, “We will keep listening, learning and improving to provide the best service while being a trusted partner to London.”

Looking Ahead. The prolonged periods of regulatory scrutiny is the latest setback for Uber, as CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has been trying to repair the company’s relations with global regulators. “We are trying our best to be excellent partners with TfL,” Khosrowshahi said during a call with investors in August.

London—with roughly 45,000 drivers and almost four million monthly riders using Uber’s service—has been one of the company’s biggest markets. A few competitors in the ride-sharing industry, including Estonia’s Bolt, India’s Ola, and Israel’s Gett, have recently entered the London market and granted short-term permits as well.

In the event of an unfavorable ruling where the license is terminated, Uber will likely challenge the decision in court like it did in 2017, the company said in its latest filing.
